ticket.title: Mysql::Error: SAVEPOINT active_record_1 does not exist: ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT active_record_1
ticket.original-body:
Hi,
I'm upgrading a Rails 2.1.1 app to 2.3 rc1 and encountering this quite a bit in my specs.
Trying to workaround it now, but thought I'd point it out. I'm surprised I haven't found mention of it anywhere else just yet.
ticket.latest-body:

version.title: Mysql::Error: SAVEPOINT active_record_1 does not exist: ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT active_record_1

version.body:
Sorry, a bit more information for ths ticket. It seems to be happening on AR exectute statements calls to TRUNCATE: e.g. 
    ActiveRecord::Base.connection.execute("TRUNCATE factsheets")
version.body-html:
Sorry, a bit more information for ths ticket.

It seems to be happening on AR exectute statements calls to TRUNCATE:

e.g.




ActiveRecord::Base.connection.execute("TRUNCATE factsheets")
version.title: Mysql::Error: SAVEPOINT active_record_1 does not exist: ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT active_record_1

version.body: Can you show more of your logs? Are the savepoints being defined?
version.body-html: Can you show more of your logs? Are the savepoints being defined?
version.title: Mysql::Error: SAVEPOINT active_record_1 does not exist: ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT active_record_1

version.body:
Unfortunately yesterday was also the day I chose to clean up my huge log files.
If you can't replicate it in your environment, let me know and I'll restore the code and try to generate a log file for you. If you can replicate it there's probably not much point in my doing it.
Thanks for the quick response.
Regards, Nicholas

Regards, Nicholas
version.title: Mysql::Error: SAVEPOINT active_record_1 does not exist: ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT active_record_1

version.body:
A basic test seems to work ok:
@@@ ruby Person::Note.transaction do Person::Note.transaction :requires_new => true do ActiveRecord::Base.connection.execute("TRUNCATE person_notes") end end @@@
Runs:
@@@ sql SQL (0.2ms) BEGIN SQL (0.1ms) SAVEPOINT active_record_1 SQL (3.0ms) TRUNCATE person_notes SQL (0.4ms) RELEASE SAVEPOINT active_record_1 SQL (0.2ms) COMMIT @@@
version.body-html:
A basic test seems to work ok:


Person::Note.transaction do
  Person::Note.transaction :requires_new => true do
    ActiveRecord::Base.connection.execute("TRUNCATE person_notes")
  end
end

Runs:


SQL (0.2ms)  BEGIN
SQL (0.1ms)  SAVEPOINT active_record_1
SQL (3.0ms)  TRUNCATE person_notes
SQL (0.4ms)  RELEASE SAVEPOINT active_record_1
SQL (0.2ms)  COMMIT
version.title: Mysql::Error: SAVEPOINT active_record_1 does not exist: ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT active_record_1
Mysql::Error: SAVEPOINT active_record_1 does not exist: ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT active_record_1

version.body:
It appears that TRUNCATE is a DDL statement, http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.1/en/implicit-commit.html, and therefore causes an implicit commit. The docs already warn against using DDL statements inside savepoints.
@@@ ruby Person::Note.transaction do ActiveRecord::Base.connection.execute("TRUNCATE person_notes") Person::Note.transaction :requires_new => true do end end @@@
Can you simply use DELETE FROM instead of TRUNCATE?
version.body-html:
It appears that TRUNCATE is a DDL statement, http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/..., and therefore causes an implicit commit. The docs already warn against using DDL statements inside savepoints.


Person::Note.transaction do
  ActiveRecord::Base.connection.execute("TRUNCATE person_notes")
  Person::Note.transaction :requires_new => true do
  end
end

Can you simply use DELETE FROM instead of TRUNCATE?
version.title: Mysql::Error: SAVEPOINT active_record_1 does not exist: ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT active_record_1

version.body:
Short answer - yes.
This code was appearing in our test code, and was probably added quickly without thought. It's not something we need supported. I wanted to point out this error was occurring though.
Thanks for the quick response.
N.
version.body-html:
Short answer - yes.

This code was appearing in our test code, and was probably added quickly without thought. It's not something we need supported. I wanted to point out this error was occurring though.

Thanks for the quick response.

N.

version.title: Mysql::Error: SAVEPOINT active_record_1 does not exist: ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT active_record_1
Mysql::Error: SAVEPOINT active_record_1 does not exist: ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT active_record_1

version.body: Is it possible to close this as something like 'Wont's Fix' instead of invalid? This is a real issue.
version.body-html: Is it possible to close this as something like 'Wont's Fix' instead of invalid? This is a real issue.
version.title: Mysql::Error: SAVEPOINT active_record_1 does not exist: ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT active_record_1

version.body: Found the same issue while running some rspec tests, but... in activerecord-2.3.1/lib/active_record/transactions.rb:182 there's the following note: === Caveats If you're on MySQL, then do not use DDL operations in nested transactions blocks that are emulated with savepoints. That is, do not execute statements like 'CREATE TABLE' inside such blocks. This is because MySQL automatically releases all savepoints upon executing a DDL operation. When #transaction is finished and tries to release the savepoint it created earlier, a database error will occur because the savepoint has already been automatically released. The following example demonstrates the problem: Model.connection.transaction do # BEGIN Model.connection.transaction(:requires_new => true) do # CREATE SAVEPOINT active_record_1 Model.connection.create_table(...) # active_record_1 now automatically released end # RELEASE savepoint active_record_1 # ^^^^ BOOM! database error! end (posted this just to help people that will google to here)
version.body-html:
Found the same issue while running some rspec tests, but...

in activerecord-2.3.1/lib/active_record/transactions.rb:182 there's the following note:

=== Caveats

If you're on MySQL, then do not use DDL operations in nested transactions blocks that are emulated with savepoints. That is, do not execute statements like 'CREATE TABLE' inside such blocks. This is because MySQL automatically releases all savepoints upon executing a DDL operation. When #transaction is finished and tries to release the savepoint it created earlier, a database error will occur because the savepoint has already been automatically released. The following example demonstrates the problem: Model.connection.transaction do # BEGIN

Model.connection.transaction(:requires_new => true) do  # CREATE SAVEPOINT active_record_1
  Model.connection.create_table(...)                    # active_record_1 now automatically released
end                                                     # RELEASE savepoint active_record_1
                                                        # ^^^^ BOOM! database error!

end

(posted this just to help people that will google to here)
version.title: Mysql::Error: SAVEPOINT active_record_1 does not exist: ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT active_record_1

version.body: I'm not sure how this should best be fixed, so for now I've documented this caveat in docrails: http://github.com/lifo/docrails/commit/0e6b9695aff6500ad48c4dd9ab61343d7090b030
version.body-html: I'm not sure how this should best be fixed, so for now I've documented this caveat in docrails: http://github.com/lifo/docrails/...
version.title: Mysql::Error: SAVEPOINT active_record_1 does not exist: ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT active_record_1

version.body: This bug appears on shoulda tests too. 20% of my tests fail with that strange error. How can I fix it? Non transactional tests are unacceptable cos them are slow. What should I do?
version.body-html:
This bug appears on shoulda tests too. 20% of my tests fail with that strange error. How can I fix it?
Non transactional tests are unacceptable cos them are slow. What should I do?
version.title: Mysql::Error: SAVEPOINT active_record_1 does not exist: ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT active_record_1

version.body:
stanislav, do not use DDL statements in your tests or code if you want to use transactions to rollback fixtures.
This is not a "won't fix" -- it's simply not fixable because most databases do not support transactional DDL statements.
version.body-html:
stanislav, do not use DDL statements in your tests or code if you want to use transactions to rollback fixtures.

This is not a "won't fix" -- it's simply not fixable because most databases do not support transactional DDL statements.
version.title: Mysql::Error: SAVEPOINT active_record_1 does not exist: ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT active_record_1

version.body: Uh, I was dreaming about "do nothing during migration to rails 2.3.x", Actually, I heave a strong filling that this errors cos shoulda contexts, but thnx anyway. Will digg my code.
version.body-html: Uh, I was dreaming about "do nothing during migration to rails 2.3.x", Actually, I heave a strong filling that this errors cos shoulda contexts, but thnx anyway. Will digg my code.
version.title: Mysql::Error: SAVEPOINT active_record_1 does not exist: ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT active_record_1

version.body:
Just wanted to add some comments that might be useful for people experiencing this with Rspec + Cucumber basically... turn off transaction fixtures... its the only way I have found to avoid this error in your tests.
Then use a global before(:each) in the Rspec & Cucumber config files/helpers that uses DatabaseCleaner
Rspec
### ruby config.after(:each) { DatabaseCleaner.clean }
Cucumber
### ruby
After('@no-transaction') do DatabaseCleaner.clean end
version.body-html:
Just wanted to add some comments that might be useful for people experiencing this with Rspec + Cucumber
basically... turn off transaction fixtures... its the only way I have found to avoid this error in your tests.

Then use a global before(:each) in the Rspec & Cucumber config files/helpers that uses DatabaseCleaner

Rspec

ruby

config.after(:each) {

DatabaseCleaner.clean

}

Cucumber

ruby

After('@no-transaction') do DatabaseCleaner.clean end
version.title: Mysql::Error: SAVEPOINT active_record_1 does not exist: ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT active_record_1

version.body-html:
sorry syntax fail - no preview sucks :(

  # rspec
  config.after(:each) {
    DatabaseCleaner.clean
  }

# cucumber After do

DatabaseCleaner.clean

end
